    <b:includable id='main'>
        <b:if cond='data:title'>
          <h2>
            <data:title/>
          </h2>
        </b:if>
        <div class='widget-content'>
          <div id='ArchiveList'>
            <div expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_ArchiveList"'>
              <b:if cond='data:style == "HIERARCHY"'>
                <b:include data='data' name='interval'/>
              </b:if>
              <b:if cond='data:style == "FLAT"'>
                <b:include data='data' name='flat'/>
              </b:if>
              <b:if cond='data:style == "MENU"'>
                <b:include data='data' name='menu'/>
              </b:if>
            </div>
          </div>
          <b:include name='quickedit'/>
        </div>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='flat' var='data'>
        <ul class='flat'>
          <b:loop values='data:data' var='i'>
            <li class='archivedate'>
              <a expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.name/>
              </a>
              (
              <data:i.post-count/>
              )
            </li>
          </b:loop>
        </ul>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='interval' var='intervalData'>
        <b:loop values='data:intervalData' var='i'>
          <ul class='hierarchy'>
            <li expr:class='"archivedate " + data:i.expclass'>
              <b:include data='i' name='toggle'/>
              <a class='post-count-link' expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.name/>
              </a>
              <span class='post-count' dir='ltr'>
                (
                <data:i.post-count/>
                )
              </span>
              <b:if cond='data:i.data'>
                <b:include data='i.data' name='interval'/>
              </b:if>
              <b:if cond='data:i.posts'>
                <b:include data='i.posts' name='posts'/>
              </b:if>
            </li>
          </ul>
        </b:loop>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='menu' var='data'>
        <select expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_ArchiveMenu"'>
          <option value=''>
            <data:title/>
          </option>
          <b:loop values='data:data' var='i'>
            <option expr:value='data:i.url'>
              <data:i.name/>
              (
              <data:i.post-count/>
              )
            </option>
          </b:loop>
        </select>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='posts' var='posts'>
        <ul class='posts'>
          <b:loop values='data:posts' var='i'>
            <li>
              <a expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.title/>
              </a>
            </li>
          </b:loop>
        </ul>
      </b:includable>

entry.title: You Donâ€™t Need a Down Payment
entry.content:
Today, I want to share with you all the options you have for an affordable down payment as a homebuyer.

What's the biggest obstacle to homeownership?

According to a recent survey, "saving enough for a down payment" comes at the top of the list. A whopping 55% of prospective homebuyers cited this as their main stumbling block.


"55% cited the lack of a down payment as their main stumbling block."


And with the continuing growth of home prices, things aren't getting any easier. In fact, homeownership rates reached a 20-year low last November.

It wasn't always like this. 

A decade ago, many lenders were offering easy, no-money-down mortgages. 

However, after the financial crisis, mortgage standards have become more restrictive. A typical mortgage now requires a 20% down payment. 

Here's the good news. 

If you have decent credit and a steady income, you might be qualified for a number of specialized programs that require no or very little down payment. Here are a few of the top options.

First, there's the USDA loan, which is valid for homes in certain regions, such as rural and suburban areas. 

With zero money down and lenient credit requirements, the USDA loan can be a great choice for many homeowners. 

Second, thereâ€™s the VA loan, which you can apply for if you or your spouse served in a branch of the military.

It's possibly the most generous zero-money-down mortgage because of low interest rates and low closing costs.

Third, there's the FHA loan. It does require a 3.5% down payment â€” still drastically more achievable than the 20% required for a conventional mortgage. 

Finally, there are a number credit unions and first-time homebuyer programs that might apply to your particular situation.

Thereâ€™s one important thing you should know.  

If you get one of these no-money-down mortgages, chances are good you will be required to pay private mortgage insurance, which can drive up your monthly payments.

Fortunately, private mortgage insurance will disappear after your mortgage balance is under 80%. Also, the money you do pay will be tax deductible in most cases.

In short, there are lots of options to make owning a home a reality for you, even if you haven't saved up tens of thousands of dollars.

If you're considering buying a home, give me a call and we can discuss your options.

Buying a Portland Home? Click here to complete your loan application.

And if you need more advice on getting a no-money-down loan, give me a call at 503-517-8581.

entry.title: Are Zestimates accurate?
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a Consultation.

Today I want to quickly touch on something I hear about all the time, the Zillow Zestimate. People always check their homeâ€™s value on Zillow, but I would be careful and highly recommend not taking it too seriously.

There are cases where the Zestimate is accurate, but those are few and far between. Zillowâ€™s estimates donâ€™t take into account any upgrades or improvements youâ€™ve made to the property, nor do they have the most accurate housing data.




Itâ€™s fun to look around to get an idea of what your home may sell for, but donâ€™t use your Zestimate to make any decisions. If you want to know the true market value of your home, I recommend that you connect with a local Realtor. I have relationships with some of the best agents in the Portland area, and would love to connect you with one.

If you have any questions for me about your home value or any other topic, give us a call or send us an email. I look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: How Does Filing Bankruptcy Affect Your Ability to Get a Mortgage?
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a Consultation.


How does bankruptcy affect your ability to get a mortgage? This is a question that comes up all the time, and an important one to consider if you're trying to buy a home.

Typically, there is a two to four year "seasoning" period after a bankruptcy where you cannot get a mortgage. However, there is a new program out there that allows people to get a mortgage without a seasoning period. If your bankruptcy was a one-time event and you have a good payment history, you're employed, and you've had a strong credit score, you might be eligible to get a mortgage with no seasoning. 

This program has been very helpful to people who allowed one unfortunate situation to occur. If you have interest in this program, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, give us a call or shoot us an email. We would love to hear from you!

link.title: How Does Filing Bankruptcy Affect Your Ability to Get a Mortgage?

entry.title: When Are Interest Rates Going to Rise?
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a Consultation.

Hey everyone, welcome back to another edition of the Moshofsky Mortgage Minute. A question I've heard a lot lately is, "When are interest rates going to go up?"

In truth, it's a very complicated answer, and nobody really knows for certain. However, at the beginning of the year, the general consensus was that in May or June rates were going to go up. Since then, a lot of inconsistent economic data has come out, detailing lower-than-expected retail sales numbers. This has created a situation where rates aren't rising in order to avoid stifling the economy.

We are looking at a rate increase soon, probably towards the latter part of this year. Anything could change between now and then, so it's important to not buy your home around interest rates, but when it makes sense for you. When that time comes, we will work our hardest to be able to get you the best rate possible.

If you have any questions for me about your current mortgage, or what current rates look like, give me a call or send me an email!

link.title: When Are Interest Rates Going to Rise?

entry.title: How Do Low Oil Prices Affect Mortgage Rates?
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a Consultation.

Welcome back to another edition of the Moshofsky Mortgage Minute, and my first video of 2015. If you've been paying attention to the economy, or have filled up your tank recently, you already know that oil prices are extremely low. Oil is trading for around $60 a barrel right now. Of course it's going to have a direct impact on gas prices, but why else should we care about oil prices?
 
You probably don't know this, but oil prices actually affect mortgage rates as well. With low oil prices, inflation is held down because heating and gas costs are lower as well. When this happens, it tends to lower mortgage rates in a similar fashion. However, if these prices are sustained for a few years, it will eventually bring the economy up, where we might see rates rise again. So, lower oil prices lead to stable mortgage rates in the short term, but higher rates in the long term.

If you have any questions, about buying a home or affording to buy a home, make sure to give me a call or send me an email. I'm here to help you succeed, and I can't wait to hear from you!

link.title: How Do Low Oil Prices Affect Mortgage Rates?

entry.title: Filing a Credit Dispute Can Disrupt Your Home Purchase!
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a FREE Consultation.

Hey guys, thanks for joining me for another edition of the Moshosky mortgage minute. Today I am going to be talking about credit report disputes.

A dispute on a credit report is when you have a disagreement with a creditor about the amount they say you owe them. If you file a dispute with them, they will also file that dispute on your credit report, which is not good to have for long.

If we check your credit report and there is a dispute on there, we cannot close your loan. It's a very tricky process and can hurt your credit score, so I have one specific piece of advice to give you:
If you have a credit dispute, get it taken care of quickly

Don't let your dispute sit there on your credit report, it will probably end up being an issue. If you have any questions about if you should dispute something on your report, give me a call. I am very familiar with navigating credit reports and can help you with whatever you need.

link.title: Filing a Credit Dispute Can Disrupt Your Home Purchase!

entry.title: The seasons are changing - what does it mean for your mortgage?
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a FREE Consultation.

 The seasons are changing here in the Portland area. The days are getting shorter and the weather is getting colder - but that's not all that's changing.

Recently, Fannie Mae has changed its guidelines regarding short sales and deeds in lieu. Instead of having to wait 2 or 3 years after having a short sale or deed in lieu, you now have to wait 4 years before you can qualify for a loan. The good news, however, is these new restrictions don't apply to FHA loans, which still maintain more lenient restrictions.

There's more - if you are thinking about getting a USDA loan, it may take a while. Turn times are longer than we've seen in 8 years; from the time you're under contract to the time you actually close may take as long as 70 days. For some reason, there seems to be a backlog causing deals to take a long time to close.

Lastly, interest rates were at their lowest just a month ago, but have recently started to come back up a little. They appear to be on the rise - all we can do is wait and see if that continues.

These are just some things to think about, as we're not sure how it will all shake out. If you are looking to buy or sell in our area, or have questions about conditions in your specific neighborhood, don't hesitate to reach out to us. We would love to give you a hand navigating this changing market!

link.title: The seasons are changing - what does it mean for your mortgage?

entry.title: What is a debt-to-income ratio?
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a FREE Consultation.

If you have gone to a lender recently in the hopes of obtaining an affordable mortgage, it's likely you've heard the phrase debt-to-income ratio thrown around. But what exactly does it mean?

Your debt-to-income ratio is a simple but crucial formula that will determine the amount of money you are able to borrow. Most programs are set at 45% debt-to-income. So, for example, if your household income is $1000 a month, your monthly bills cannot exceed $450. These bills include your car payments, students loans, and credit card payments, among others.

In essence, you need to be sure you are budgeting properly so you can get the mortgage that is best for you. We go out of our way to make ourselves accessible to you, so don't hesitate to give us a call or shoot us an email with any questions you have on the topic. We'd be glad to help you out.

entry.title: The Easing of Jumbo Mortgage Guidelines
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a FREE Consultation.

Welcome back, everybody. Today I want to take a minute to talk to you about some pretty big news. Finally, jumbo mortgages are starting to ease up a little bit on some of their restrictions.
 
If you aren't already aware, a jumbo mortgage is simply any loan that is above $417,000. For the past 7 or 8 years, these types of mortgages have been really difficult to get your hands on. They have been riddled with red tape, and a lot of restrictions associated with them. Now, however, we have seen a lot of those restrictions ease up.

The debt to income ratio required to qualify is still 43%, a tough number, but they are now starting to allow some 10% down jumbo loans up to a certain purchase price. This is huge because in the past the general thought has been that you need 20% down to qualify for a jumbo loan.

This is huge for those of you thinking about making a purchase in this type of price range, because qualifying for this type of loan is half of the cost of what it usually is. If you think that this type of loan could be a fit for you, please give me a call or send me an e-mail so we can talk. 

I would be happy to share with you some details about the jumbo mortgage guidelines and making sure you are happy is my #1 concern!

link.title: The Easing of Jumbo Mortgage Guidelines

Portland Mortgage Minute Update
Thanks for tuning back in to my Mortgage Minute Update for the Portland area. I've got some great news for you because house prices are up and mortgage rates are down. If you have purchased a home in the Portland area in the last 2-3 years you're probably sitting on a nice chunk of equity.

One way to leverage some of that equity is to consider getting rid of your mortgage insurance. If you have FHA loans, this may be your opportunity to capitalize. FHA is a great program, but its mortgage insurance program is slightly expensive, and with your new equity you may be able to get into a conventional loan.
 
With a conventional loan you would have no mortgage insurance, lower payments, and long-term stability.
 
I have done this for many of my clients and I would be happy to do it for you as well. This is just one way to improve your situation even further.

Please contact me via phone or email with any questions. I look forward to speaking with you.

entry.title: Checking Your Credit Score Helps Your Lender Guide You on a Successful Path
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I build my business by referral, so if you know of someone who could use the expert advise of a mortgage lender or finance officer, please forward this email to them, or reply back with their contact information and I'll gently reach out to them. If you have any questions about the mortgage and finance industry, please don't hesitate to give me a call. I'd be more than happy to provide a FREE Consultation.

Does it Hurt Your Score to Check on Your Credit?
This is a question that people ask me all the time. To make this answer very short: it does hurt your score when you check your credit, but the damage is extremely miniscule.

On average your score will drop 2-4 points when you check it, and this is not going to ruin your borrowing ability. I have never seen someone with good credit have their score ruined by just checking up on their credit.

My advice for you if you're looking for a home is to get your credit checked before you start searching. This will minimize any bumps in the road and it will allow me to understand where you're at with your debts and payments. The benefits really outweigh the costs here. If there is something that needs to be taken care of, this will allow me ample time to get it taken care of. 

So, don't be afraid to get your credit checked. It's going to put you on the right path and allow us to lead you to a successful real estate transaction.

You should also know that when you do get your credit checked, there is a 2-3 week window where you can get it checked again with no penalties against your score. 

If you're looking to buy a home in the Portland area and need a mortgage lender, please feel free to contact me. I am here to answer any and all of your questions. 

You can contact me at (503) 880-6533 or email me at adam@mtgxps.com

link.title: Checking Your Credit Score Helps Your Lender Guide You on a Successful Path

entry.title: What NOT to Do During the Home Buying Process
entry.content:
Welcome back to my Market Minute update. Today I am going to focus on a document that we send to every single one of our clients when we're going forward with a transaction here in Portland. We like to educate our clients as well as give them the best service possible. This includes instructing them on what to do, and also what not to do.

What NOT to Do During the Home Buying Process
  1. Don't change or terminate your employment: At the tail end of every transaction we will call your employer to verify that you are still working. Even if you're stuck in a bad situation at work, it's best to persevere because you will be faced with double the problems if you quit or change jobs. However, if you absolutely must quit, be sure to tell us about it because we will do our best to work out a plan for you. Avoid this because it causes nightmares for us as well as for you.
  2. Don't Apply for New Credit: You want to avoid new inquiries from showing up on your credit report because this is always a red flag to us and we will have to address these issues. This will only prolong the buying process, which will only cost both us and you time and money.
  3. Don't Purchase Major New Items: When you're buying a home, you don't need to be buying a new car or boat as well. Not only will this strain your finances, but it will also affect your credit score. Wait until you settle your larger financials with us and then go ahead and buy yourself a new car or whatever it is that you desire.
  4. Don't Shift Money Between Accounts: When we look at your bank statements and see large amounts of money transferred or deposited into various accounts, we have to trace every single one of those transactions. Sometimes this can be unavoidable, but it's best not to do this when it is not necessary. It makes our job more difficult which will slow the process of your purchase and cost you more time and money.
Hopefully this information has been a benefit to you, but keep in mind this is only a brief list and explanation of things NOT to do when buying a home. More information can be found at www.AdamMoshofksy.com

If you want more information about this or if you have inquiries regarding Portland real estate, then please contact me at (503) 880-6533 or email me at Adam@mtgxps.com

link.title: What NOT to Do During the Home Buying Process

entry.title: The housing market is competitive - You need to be prepared
entry.content:
Do you have a friend or family member who is thinking about buying a home, or refinancing their current home? I have an easy and simple loan calculator on my website. Click here!

Hello again, and welcome back to my Market Minute update. I'll be talking today about how to compete in our highly aggressive market here in Portland. 
You've probably noticed that most homes are receiving multiple offers, and if you're competing against cash buyers, then I have some ways that you can leverage yourself against them. 
  • Get Pre-Approved: Do this ahead of time. Get all your necessary documents in order so that you can get a headstart on the property you want. If necessary, I can assist you in this process. 
  • Minutes and Hours do matter: Do not delay, because the market here moves very, very fast. You need to be ready to compete for a home when the opportunity arises.
If you need any help in this process, be sure to contact me because I am extremely responsive and can get you what you need fast. I work at the speed of the market, so please use me as your resource.
Contact me at (503) 880-6533 or email me at Adam@mtgxps.com

link.title: The housing market is competitive - You need to be prepared

entry.title: Where is the Mortgage Market Headed in 2014?
entry.content:
What is the mortgage market going to look like in 2014? Most industry experts do anticipate that at some point in the year we'll hit a 5% 30-year fixed rate. As most of you know, we've been below 5% for the last couple of years, which is mainly due to the federal reserve's purchase of mortgage-backed securities. But as they pull back you should expect to see rates go up.

Despite a slight increase in rates, 5% is still historically low. Also, inventory is expected to remain tight so this means competition among buyers will remain fierce.

In addition to these projected outcomes you can expect a healthy amount of new changes in the mortgage world. That's something I can help guide you through, so please do not hesitate to call me at (503) 880-6533 or email me at Adam@mtgxps.com.

link.title: Where is the Mortgage Market Headed in 2014?

entry.title: Government Shutdown Risks Hurting The Housing Recovery
entry.content:
From: http://www.forbes.com/sites/morganbrennan/2013/10/01/heres-how-the-government-shutdown-will-affect-housing/

By:  Morgan Brennan, Forbes Staff

The government shutdown is here. Whether itâ€™s not being able to get a new Social Security card or visit a national park, Americans will immediately feel the effects. But thereâ€™s one bright spot of the economy that stands to be affected as well: housing.

One of the biggest questions regarding the shutdown and how it will affect housing has revolved around the mortgage market, specifically prospective buyersâ€™ access to new home loans. After all, more than 90% of all loan activity is underwritten, insured, or owned by the government and its affiliated entities.

Initially at least, the mortgage market is likely to be only minimally impacted. New loans will continue to push through most government agency pipelines. What will change is how long the process takes, as many agencies expect to experience delays.

Mortgages purchased and securitized by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will be unaffected because their operations are paid for by fees charged to lenders. And the Department of Veterans Affairs will continue to guarantee mortgages for Americans that have served in the military since these loans are funded by user fees as well.

But if the government shutdown of 1995-1996 is any indicator, the process will take longer than usual. â€œLoan Guaranty certificates of eligibility and certificates of reasonable value were delayed,â€ the VA warned in its September 25th contingency plan.

Where there has been mounting concern is the Federal Housing Administration, which currently endorses about 15% of the entire single-family mortgage market. Several media outlets recently reported that the FHA would be unable to endorse any single-family loans and that no staff would be available underwrite and approve new loans.

That prospect would be somewhat worrisome â€“ if it were actually true. The FHAâ€™s Office of Single Family Housing will indeed remain open for business, albeit with a smaller staff. â€œFHA will be able to endorse single family loans during the shutdown. A limited number of FHA staff will be available to underwrite and approve new loans,â€ the report now states. In other words, other lendersâ€™ loans will continue to be insured and some in-house lending will continue to take place at a reduced rate.

The reason for that mix-up: the initial draft of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Developmentâ€™s contingency plan mistakenly stated that single-family loan operations would cease. The report was amended over the weekend.

The FHAâ€™s single-family loan operations are funded through multi-year appropriations, meaning their budget is not tied to the governmentâ€™s standoff over funding for the new fiscal year that starts in October. On the other hand, what will be more affected is the agencyâ€™s Multifamily Housing Office, which is funded through yearly appropriations.

â€œBecause we are able to endorse loans, we donâ€™t expect the impact on the housing market to be significant, as long as the shutdown is brief,â€ continues the HUD report. â€œIf the shutdown lasts and our commitment authority runs out, we do expect that potential homeowners will be impacted, as well as home sellers and the entire housing market.â€

One government lender that will indeed suspend its home loan activity, however, is the Department of Agriculture. The USDA says that no new housing loans or guarantees will be issued through its Rural Development programs in a shutdown. The department also warns that such a scenario could cause â€œa setback in construction start-up,â€ and if the shutdown lasts for an extended period, â€œa substantial reduction in housing available in rural areas relative to population.â€

â€œThe government doesnâ€™t generally approve loans, they basically just insure them,â€ says Don Frommeyer, president of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers and a vice president at Amtrust Mortgage Funding. â€œFor the most part you arenâ€™t going to see much of a hit in the mortgage market unless it goes for a long period of time.â€

If it does stretch on, he adds, the worry will be what mortgage rates do in a market shrouded in fiscal uncertainty and how that will affect the home buying, especially in light of recent rate spikes.

Home lending aside, many economists and real estate experts are keeping a close watch on how Americans will react to this shutdown. â€œAdministratively everything should keep moving along, but itâ€™s more about the confidence of consumers and whether they perceive that the government shutdown could lead to a recession,â€ says Lawrence Yun, chief economist at the National Association of Realtors.

Moodyâ€™s Analytics chief economist Mark Zandi recently told the Senate Budget Committee that a partial shutdown could shave as much as 1.4 percentage points off of fourth quarter economic growth if it drags on for several weeks.

Americansâ€™ confidence in their ability to buy and sell homes hit a record high in May, according to a Fannie Mae survey. Since then, as mortgage rates jumped more than a percentage point, that confidence level has plateaued.  If prospective homebuyers fear that the countryâ€™s economic recovery will stall, or worse slip back into recession, they will pull back on purchases, worries Yun.

â€œHome sales is always the first housing variable that changes so one would see sales declining and that would naturally lead to more inventory on the market and eventually put pressure on prices,â€ he says. But that would be a worst-case scenario based on a long-term shutdown.

Jed Kolko, chief economist at Trulia TRLA +6.43%, notes that if the shutdown lasts longer than a few days, the first places to feel the impact will be local economies with large concentrations of federal government workers. Metro areas like Washington, D.C. and Bethesda, Md., where 19% and 13% respectively of total local wages go to federal employees, would be the feel the negative effects of unpaid furloughs and with them, tightened consumer spending and weakening local economic growth. Though not all will be equally affected, other metro areas like Virginia Beach, Va., Honolulu, Hawaii, and Dayton, Ohio are areas that Kolko is keeping an eye on: â€œWhether there is a big effect depends on how long the shutdown lasts, how long people think the shutdown lasts, and whether people get back-pay. All those things matter for the impact.â€

Still others are worrying even more about the next fiscal standoff, in  mid-October, surrounding the debt ceiling debate and its accompanying threat of debt default by the U.S.  â€With the threat of an impending partial government shutdown and yet another battle over the nationâ€™s debt ceiling, in particular, we are really messing with fire right nowâ€”even if it doesnâ€™t seem to bother some legislators,â€ says Stan Humphries, chief economist at Zillow.

â€œBut the effects of a government default associated with the impending debt-ceiling deadline would be more pronounced because of its greater impact on domestic and international markets. This will rattle consumers and investors alike, slow down the overall economic recovery and further slow the housing recovery, which is already undergoing a moderation in the pace of home value gains due to rising mortgage rates,â€ he warns.

link.title: Government Shutdown Risks Hurting The Housing Recovery

entry.title: USDA Changes Coming?
entry.content:
Hi guys, this is Adam Moshofsky with the Moshofsky Mortgage Minute and welcome back to my video blog. Thank you for joining me.

Today I want to touch on a topic that we touched on a little while ago: the USDA program. Well, theyâ€™re at it again. Come October 1st, we are not sure yet if there is going to be some boundary changes in the USDA lines. There is a new foreign bill that is being proposed and depending on the outcome of the vote on this bill current USDA eligible properties may lose their eligibility. We will make sure to keep you updated as this plays out over the next few weeks, but if you are a USDA buyer and you are looking at homes in USDA areas (especially Newburg, Sherwood, Forest Grove) this could affect you if it does not go our way. What that means is if you want to guarantee a USDA loan, you will have to be in contract and we have to submit your loan to USDA no later than September 30th of this year.

We would just like to let you guys know that if you are a USDA buyer this could definitely affect you and I will keep you posted on the results down the road. If you have any questions on this, I am very easy to reach. Give me a call at (503) 517-8581 or shoot me an email at AMoshofsky@mtgxps.com. Thanks for watching!

entry.title: Should I Buy My Rate Down?
entry.content:
Hi guys, this is Adam Moshofsky. Welcome to Moshofsky Mortgage Minute, thank you for joining me!

Today I want to touch on a topic that Iâ€™m sure some of you have heard about recently if you have been looking for a mortgage. Does it make sense to buy your rate down?

Now, there are many ways this can be shown. It can be called points, discount fees or rate buy down; they are all the same thing. They are all designed to get your rate lower than the current market rate and it does cost you to do that.

For example, letâ€™s say it will cost you $1,000 to buy your rate down but itâ€™s only going to save you $20 a month. Well, itâ€™s going to take you 50 months to recuperate your upfront investment, a little over 30 years. So are you 100% sure that you are going to be in that home for four years? If not then buying the rate down doesnâ€™t make a lot of sense.

This is a case-by-case. Some people know they will be in their home long terms, others do not. So if Iâ€™m lucky enough to talk to you about this, Iâ€™d love to craft this especially for your situation to see whatâ€™s going to make sense for you.

So if you have any questions on this, Iâ€™d love to hear you from you. You can call me 503.880.6533 or send me an email at amoshofsky@mtgxps.com

link.title: Should I Buy My Rate Down?

entry.title: Why Are We Seeing a Jump in Interest Rates?
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Hey guys, Adam Moshofsky here and welcome to the Moshofsky Mortgage Minute, thank you for joining me. Today I'm going to touch on a topic that's affecting everybody and I don't know if you've heard yet but interest rates are up, and I'm going to explain why.

Recently, the Federal Reserve has been purchasing $85 billion a month in mortgage-backed securities. What that's doing is keeping demand high and keeping interest rates low. Last week, a comment was made that reminded the market that eventually, whether it's later this year or early next year, they will be rescinding that order of $85 billion a month.

Just that little reminder was enough to send the markets into chaos. Essentially, we had a huge selloff because they know the demand will be less down the road and what that does is create a HUGE jump in interest rates. So, we had a jump of around 1% across the board on all interest rates.

So. that is why you're seeing rates go up. Who knows when it's going to happen in the future? Time will tell, but I wanted to explain to my database and my friends and family why this is happening. If you have any questions or anything regarding mortgage, please let me know I am here for you and would love to be your go-to person. Thanks again for joining me, and I'll see you next time.

link.title: Why Are We Seeing a Jump in Interest Rates?

entry.title: Borrow from Your 401k for Your Down Payment
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

This is Adam Moshofsky and welcome to the Moshofsky Mortgage Minute. Thanks as always for joining me! Today I want to touch on a topic that seems to be coming up and up very commonly right now and that is how do I come up with a down payment to purchase a home? As you guys know the housing market right now is really on fire and so a lot of people are looking for ways to get into homes. 

Well, most programs are going to require a down payment. And right now a really popular way to get a down payment is to borrow from your 401k. Now that is not for everybody. If you're a senior citizen and plan on retiring soon that's not something I would recommend.  If you're somewhere before that I think it's a great way to leverage that retirement fund and put it into a house as long as you're making a wise investment.

So, how that works is you are billed to borrow from your 401k, tax free, penalty free. And you do have a repayment period, could be two, three, five, ten years and you will have a monthly payment to pay that back. But it is a very effective way to get a down payment. It's perfectly legitimate and okay to use for the lenders. So it's a way for you to leverage your retirement account and get into the housing market, whether it's now or down the road. 

So, I have executed this many times if you want some help on how to do it I would be happy to show you the steps to take. All my contact information is below and I'd love to hear from you guys. Thanks again, see you next time!

Adam Moshofsky        (503) 880-6533      adam@mtgxps.com

link.title: Borrow from Your 401k for Your Down Payment

entry.title: List Your Home or Refinance?
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >> 

Hey guys, this is Adam Moshofsky and welcome to the Moshofsky Mortgage Minute. Thank you for joining me. Today I want to talk about a topic that Iâ€™m sure some of you are thinking about: Do you sell or list your home in a very hot sellersâ€™ market right now or do you take advantage of the rates and refinance using the HARP loan or some other refinance product. Itâ€™s a very tough situation so itâ€™s going to come down to what your needs and wants are.  

I would be more than happy to sit down and talk to you about those with you on an individual basis. Iâ€™m sure you know right now the inventory is very, very low giving sellers a lot of control over a negotiate right now. Also, HARP has been extended to 2015. If you are not familiar with what HARP is, it is the refinance program that allows you to refinance even though you may be underwater. So, all of a sudden you have two really good options and itâ€™s time to decide which way to go. I would be happy to sit down with you and talk to you about your options and let you know everything that I can tell you.

Give me a call at (503) 880-6533 or email me at adam@mtgxps.com for all your mortgage needs. Thanks and have a great day.

entry.title: How to Keep Your Credit Score High
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Hey guys, this is Adam Moshofsky and welcome to the Moshofsky Mortgage Minute. Today I want to talk about credit scores and how to keep them high so when you do apply for a mortgage, we can get you the best rate possible. Typically, when you have a credit card, if you have over a 50% balance on your limit, you are going to get a credit score hit. So, you do want to keep your balances under that 50% threshold because that will definitely help your credit scores in the long run. 

Ideally, you will keep a small amount on the card every month. If you pay it off every month, sometimes the credit bureaus wonâ€™t give you credit for it. If you keep a $10 credit on your card every month and pay interest on that $10, it will raise your credit scores fairly quickly. Another thing you want to do, is if you have an old account that you no longer use but have had for years, donâ€™t close it. If you close it, all that good payment history will go away and no longer be computed into your score. So, even if you donâ€™t use it, keep it; it will help your score when you apply for a mortgage. 

My job is to get you the best rate possible and to have your credit score as high as possible will help me do that. If you have any questions about your personal credit situation or anything else mortgage related, please call me at (503) 880-6533 or email me at adam@mtgxps.com and I will be happy to help. Thanks and have a great day!

link.title: How to Keep Your Credit Score High

entry.title: FHA Announces More Big Changes
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Hey guys, it's Adam Moshofsky. Welcome to Moshofsky Mortgage Minute, thank you for joining me. Today I want to touch on another topic that I've talked about before - FHA is at it again! They are raising their mortgage insurance premiums again April 1, 2013 and that's going to effect anybody that has not ordered the FHA case number by then. So basically all you need to do is be in contract on a new home before April 1, and you'll avoid the changes.

The increase is from 1.25% annually to 1.35% annually and that's in monthly mortgage insurance. It's not an incredible jump, but it is a jump and we've seen this from them before. Basically, FHA is trying to pull themselves out of the market a little bit and let the convential, private lenders jump in and take up more of the slack.

I just wanted to keep you guys up to date, especially if you are an FHA buyer if this does affect you, call me and I'd love to talk to you about your situation. Thanks again for watching my videos and have a great day!


AMoshofsky@mtgxps.com                                          503-517-8581

entry.title: Fiscal Cliff Aftermath - How it Affects You
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Today I wanted to touch on my last video on the fiscal cliff, essentially the aftermath of the fiscal cliff. Two quick points: 1). As expected, they did come to an agreement and as expected rates did pop up a little bit. Now, this is not a surprise and we were projecting that this would happen but the bump was very, very small.

So if you're looking to refinance or still looking to make a purchase, you will still get an amazing rate. We are still in the low-to-mid 3's for most of the 30-year fixed products. It was a modest bump and again, not a surprise. 2). Another big thing that came out of it is that the private mortgage insurance, also known as monthly mortgage insurance, will be tax deductible in 2013. This is a huge win for homeowners! If you are looking to make a purchase in 2013 or if you already own a home, you will get this tax deduction if you qualify for it. So this is great news for homeowners out of the fiscal cliff deal.

These are my main points I wanted to follow up on the fiscal cliff; if you guys have any questions your current mortgage situation, or you are thinking about purchasing or refinancing please let me know. You can shoot me an email at adam@mtgxps.com or call me at (503) 880-6533.

entry.title: How the Fiscal Cliff Will Affect Your Mortgage
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Hey guys, this is Adam Moshofsky and welcome to the Moshofsky Mortgage Minute. Today I wanted to touch on a topic that is all over the news: the fiscal cliff. But, specifically, how is the fiscal cliff going to affect mortgage rates? There are two general thoughts on this. The first is, if congress does reach an agreement and if it is bi-partisan and generally people are happy with it, most likely we will see an increase in rates in the short term. On the other side, if we do not reach an agreement, if we go over the fiscal cliff, it is likely that rates will decrease a little bit more. Now we are already at record low rates, so we have yet to see where those rates can go, but itâ€™s possible that they could go down further. So, this could help or hurt you in your current situation whether you are looking to refinance or purchase. I would love to help you and talk to you specifically about your situation to see if we can improve it.

Today I want to talk about a topic that is very hot right now and that is: how long does it take you to buy after you have gone into a foreclosure? Since the economic hardships of the late 2000s we have had a lot of people in that situation, whether it be a short sale, foreclosure or bankruptcy, people want to know â€œHow long do I have to wait?â€

Well, it depends on what loan program you are using because every loan program has different guidelines. For example, if you are in to do a conventional loan for a closure, the technical guideline is seven years. If you want to do a FHA loan itâ€™s three years and if you are a veteran and you want to apply for a VA loan, itâ€™s two years. entry.title: Oregon Rural Real Estate Market Set to Undergo Changes
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

If you are looking to buy or sell a home in rural Oregon, especially in the Newberg or Sherwood communities, there are some important decisions being made in the real estate realm that you need to be aware of.  Recently, on October 1st, the USDA had a review regarding the communities of Newberg and Sherwood and the eligibility of homebuyers in these communities to receive a USDA loan.  However, there will be another review on March 27th of 2013, so here are a few things you need to know before that date.

What is a USDA Loan?
A USDA loan, also called a Rural Development Loan, is a government insured loan that allows you to purchase a home with zero money down.  USDA loans offer 100% financing to qualified buyers, and allow for the closing cost to either be paid by the seller or financed into the loan.  USDA loan eligibility is determined by three factors: credit worthiness, USDA loan income restrictions, and where you live. 

What Should I do Before the Next Review?  
There is a very good chance that the March 27threview will determine that homes in the Newberg and Sherwood areas will no longer qualify to receive USDA loans.  If you are a buyer looking at homes in this area, you need to make sure that you are pre-approved for the USDA loan now and start looking seriously for a property because you may lose your eligibility to use this loan after the first quarter of 2013. If you were to lose your eligibility for this loan, you would not get 100% financing and that could be the difference in landing your dream home and staying put.  If you are a seller, over the next few months there will be many USDA buyers touring homes in your community, so you want ready your home for market to cater to these individuals.  If you wait until after March of next year, you will lose out on a very serious buying contingent.
If you have any questions regarding USDA loans or any other real estate needs, contact your local mortgage banker.

link.title: Oregon Rural Real Estate Market Set to Undergo Changes

entry.title: The 15 Year Fixed Mortgage
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>


As you have probably heard, interest rates across the country are at historic lows.  Due to these amazing rates, a savvy play in this real estate environment has been to change your mortgage from a 30-year fixed interest rate to a 15-year fixed interest rate.  15-year fixed interest rates are hovering right below 3%, which makes them very tempting to many home owners.  If you choose to switch to a 15-year fixed, your monthly payment will go up; however, over the long haul, this switch could save you tens of thousands of dollars.  The current low interest rates on both a 15-year and 30-year fixed rate make both of these products extremely appealing.  The best thing you can do is speak with your local mortgage broker to crunch the numbers and decide if now is the right time to refinance your home.

entry.title: Portland Mortgage Update August 2012
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Due to historically low rates in the housing market, many people are wondering if they can purchase a new home without having to sell their current home.  Whether as a potential buyer you are looking to upgrade your primary residency, invest in a home for a family member, or purchase a home solely for investment purposes, there are many options available to you.  There are a few things to consider before purchasing an additional home.  The first is, whether or not you will be able to rent out your home.  The second is if you are able to rent out your home, can you use the rental income of your home.  Because each time a person looks at buying a new home without selling their current home is a unique situation, you should schedule a time to speak with a local mortgage broker.

entry.title: Portland Mortgage Update July 2012
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

The current real estate market is extremely competitive for home buyers out there.  The housing inventory is very low, there are multiple offers on each house, and in many situations houses are going for above list price.   However, if you are a buyer in the current market, you can get a competitive edge by organizing all of your financial documents as soon as possible.  With all of your finances in a row, you can get a pre-approval letter from your mortgage broker as soon as a house goes on market.  With the pre-approval letter already written, you can quickly place a bid on the house and start the closing process.
